occurrences.line_text: But Britomart would not thereto assent,
But now of Britomart it here doth neede,
Bent to reuenge on blamelesse Britomart
Doe fight with Britomart:
He wist right well, that it was Britomart,
So both to wreake their wrathes on Britomart agreed.
When Britomart with sharpe auizefull eye
Thereat full inly blushed Britomart;
To whom thus Britomart, Certes Sir knight,
Till Britomart him fairely thus behight;
Vnto the loue of noble Britomart,
Where sorie Britomart had lost her late;
And so and so to noble Britomart:
Of Britomart after long tedious toyle,
That Britomart heard not the shrilling sound,
Britomart fightes with many Knights,
Were Britomart, and gentle Scudamour,
Full oftentimes did Britomart assay
To weet faire Britomart, them late had foyled
But Britomart did him importune hard,
Which Britomart him gaue, when he did her prouoke.
Talus brings newes to Britomart
Yet his owne loue, the noble Britomart,
Then Britomart vnto a bowre was brought;
There all that night remained Britomart,
Now mote ye know (that which to Britomart
Britomart comes to Isis Church,
Vnto whose temple when as Britomart
Such was the Goddesse; whom when Britomart
In which stout Britomart her selfe did rest,
Which Britomart withstood with courage stout,
Full sad and sorrowfull was Britomart
Faire Britomart in languor and vnrest,
The noble Britomartis her arayd,
Ne ye faire Britomartis, thus arayd,
Through heauy stroke of Britomartis hond.
Strange were the words in Britomartis eare;
Awayted there for Britomarts returne,
And of the hardie Britomarts successe:
Whom that most noble Briton Prince so long
And Briton fields with Sarazin bloud bedyde,
The Briton Prince recou'ring his stolne sword,
Thrise happy man, (said then the Briton knight)
An auncient booke, hight Briton moniments,
A chronicle of Briton kings,
Yet oft the Briton kings against them strongly swayd.
So mightily the Briton Prince him rouzd
The famous Briton Prince and Faerie knight,
To aske this Briton Mayd, what vncouth wind,
Be to the Briton babe, that shalbe borne,
So shall the Briton bloud their crowne againe reclame.
Through fine abusion of that Briton mayd:
Vpon all which the Briton Prince made seasure,
Till Scudamour, and that same Briton maide,
Whom when the Briton Prince a farre beheld
The Briton Prince him readie did awayte,
The Briton Prince was sore empassionate,
The noble Briton Prince, with his braue Peare;
And sent redresse thereof by this braue Briton Knight.
Then wote ye that I am a Briton borne,
What fortune to the Briton Prince did lite,
Tho when the Britonesse saw all the rest
Yet the bold Britonesse was nought ydred,
The warlike Britonesse her soone addrest,
At last the most redoubted Britonesse,
So soone as she with that braue Britonesse
The which that Britonesse had to them donne,
Where being layd, the wrothfull Britonesse
The land, which warlike Britons now possesse,
Of Brutus, nor of Britons glory auncient.
And enuying the Britons blazed fame,
And taking armes, the Britons to her drew;
Was of the Britons first crownd Soueraine:
The weary Britons, whose war-hable youth
The feeble Britons, broken with long warre,
Of his Norueyses, to assist the Britons fone.
Whiles thus thy Britons do in languour pine,
Then shall the Britons, late dismayd and weake,
Of Britons eke with him attonce shall dye;
Shalbe expird of Britons regiment.
The Britons, for their sinnes dew punishment,
That in this thraldome Britons shall abide,
Enioy the crowne, which they from Britons wonne
A band of Britons ryding on forray
For noble Britons sprong from Troians bold,
Subdewd with losse of many Britons bold:
But this to you, ï¿½ Britons, most pertaines,
Which mote the feebled Britons strongly flancke
And following Dee, which Britons long ygone
Fights with Cymochles, whiles his bro-
To blazon broad emongst her learned throng:
Did spred so broad, that heauens light did hide,
Now when broad day the world discouered has,
And towards it a broad high way that led,
Whom broad awake she finds, in troublous fit,
By muddy shore of broad seuen-mouthed Nile,
All keepe the broad high way, and take delight
As two broad Beacons, set in open fields,
With his broad sayles, about him soared round:
Close vnder his left wing, then broad displayd.
Can high aduance his broad discoloured brest,
The Northerne wind his wings did broad display
Like a broad table did it selfe dispred,
On his broad shield, bit not, but glauncing fell
Through which a beaten broad high way did trace,
To a broad gate, all built of beaten gold:
That her broad beauties beam great brightnes threw
With braunches broad dispred and body great,
And his broad braunches, laden with rich fee,
With boughes and braunches, which did broad dilate
Her bared bosome she doth broad display;
Whiles on his broad round backe they softly slid
That their broad flaggie finnes no fome did reare,
They trembling stood, and made a long broad dyke,
With scutchins gilt and banners broad displayd:
Led with thy prayses and broad-blazed fame,
To stirre vp strife, and troublous contecke broch:
Shall backe repulse the valiaunt Brockwell twise,
So forth she comes: her brightnesse brode doth blaze;
Full large he was of limbe, and shoulders brode,
With the brode shadow of an hoarie hill,
Into an Island spatious and brode,
That at his backe a brode Capuccio had,
Vpon the brim of his brode plated shield,
Of that great turney, which was blazed brode,
Ne hostes of men with banners brode dispred,
And Psamathe, for her brode snowy brests;
Which bore the Sunne brode blazed in a golden field.
To weather his brode sailes, by chaunce hath spide
That her brode spreading wings did wyde vnfold;
At length breakes forth, and brode displayes his smyling hew.
Couered with mossie shrubs, which spredding brode
His brode black wings had through the heauens wyde
And quite a sunder broke. Forth flowed fresh
Doth belch out flames, and rockes in peeces broke,
She broke his wanton darts, and quenched base desire.
That broke the violence of his intent,
The Prince now stood, hauing his weapon broke;
Those Champions broke on them, that forst them fly,
Broke their rude troupes, and orders did confound,
Perforce their studies broke, and them besought
Out of his hold, and broke his caitiue bands,
On whose sharpe clifts the ribs of vessels broke,
And broke his staffe, with which he charmed semblants sly.
Guyon broke downe, with rigour pittilesse;
He found him not; for he had broke his band,
Broke into open fire and rage extreme,
Their swerds & speres were broke, & hauberques rent;
And that great brasen pillour broke in peeces small.
Broke vp the listes, their armes away to rend;
And with her body, as a buckler, broke
His wonted warlike weapons all he broke,
That all his ribs he quite in peeces broke,
And broke his sword in twaine, and all his armour sperst.
And broke their bowes, and did their shooting marre,
And broke his sword, for feare of further harmes,
That his owne waight his necke asunder broke,
And broke their speares; yet neither has forgon
He broke, and did his bowels disentrayle;
His wrath on him, that first occasion broke.
Out of their ambush broke, and gan him to inuade.
Of that displeasure, broke his bag-pipe quight,
From thence into the sacred Church he broke,
Or fault of men, he broke his yron chaine,
The broken reliques of their former cruelty.
Like the old ruines of a broken towre,
False traitour miscreant, thou broken hast
Throwing away her broken chaines and bands,
That all in peeces it was broken fond,
The feeble Britons, broken with long warre,
Tyde with her broken girdle, it a part
Her heart nigh broken was with weary toyle,
Of broken bowes and arrowes shiuered short,
And on a broken reed he still did stay
There were rent robes, and broken scepters plast,
Witnesse their broken bandes there to be seene,
(That well I wote) the heads of many broken speares.
Yet would not let their battell so be broken,
A broken sword within a bloodie field;
And almost would his balances haue broken:
His timbered bones all broken rudely rumbled:
Was lately broken by some fortune ill;
Is broken with some fearefull dreames affright,
Though nothing whole, but all to brusd and broken,
Dealing iust iudgements, that mote not be broken
Certes (said he) loth were I to haue broken
So huge a burden on such broken geare,
His dearest ioynt he sure had broken quight.
Into their cloysters now he broken had,
And in his hand a burning brond he hath,
As where th'Almighties lightning brond does light,
The which doth quench the brond of hellish smart,
Her hellish brond hath kindled with despight,
He hath a sword, that flames like burning brond.
Now brought to him a flaming fire brond,
And quench the brond of his conceiued ire.
Kindled through his infernall brond of spight,
That I can carue with this inchaunted brond
From the third brunt of this my fatall brond:
To yield wide way to his hart-thrilling brond;
And did his yron brond so fast applie,
Like as the lightning brond from riuen skie,
But he doth with his raging brond diuide
And with his brondiron round about him layd;
Another did the dying bronds repaire
And with his club bet backe his brondyron bright
Shame burning brond-yrons in her hand did hold:
Great Brontes, and Astraeus, that did shame
Farre passing Bronteus, or Pynacmon great,
Her scattred brood, soone as their Parent deare
Arose the virgin borne of heauenly brood,
Th'Eternall brood of glorie excellent:
And coleblacke steedes yborne of hellish brood,
With stonie eyes; and all the hellish brood
In doubt to deeme her borne of earthly brood;
And bid her ioy of that her happie brood;
Sith to thee is vnknowne the cradle of thy brood.
And her base Elfin brood there for thee left.
And in the hollow earth haue their eternall brood.
The martiall brood accustomed to fight:
Of those same antique Peres, the heauens brood,
Of hungry whelpes, his battailous bold brood,
For not as other wemens commune brood,
The losse of her deare brood, her deare delight:
For she at first was borne of hellish brood,
And bright, that seemed borne of Angels brood,
Phorcys, the father of that fatall brood,
They doe thy linage, and thy Lordly brood;
Had left her now but fiue of all that brood:
Saue an huge nation of the Geaunts broode,
No lesse then do her elder sisters broode.
Borne of the brooding of Echidna base,
And gan abhorre her broods vnkindly crime,
Als his faire Leman, flying through a brooke,
But fairely well she thriu'd, and well did brooke
Whether she would them loue, or in her liking brooke.
And fast beside a little brooke did pas
And burning all to ashes, powr'd it downe the brooke.
Flowne at a flush of Ducks, foreby the brooke,
Through slipperie footing, fell into the brooke,
With which he seldome fished at the brooke,
Ne could he brooke the coldnesse of the stony masse.
In the next brooke, by who[m] that feend shold be fordonne.
And drinke of euery brooke, when thirst my throte doth boyle.
On Phrygian Paris by Plexippus brooke,
Soft rombling brookes, that gentle slomber drew;
As that in riuers swim, or brookes doe wade.
The whyles their beasts there in the budded broomes
His eldest brother, burning all with rage
The brother of Cymochles, both which arre
Vnto his brother, whom Cymochles men did call.
Good or bad (gan his brother fierce reply)
And th'other brother gan his helme vnlace,
And match his brother proud in battailous array.
Which when his brother saw, fraught with great griefe
Als when his brother saw the red bloud rayle
His brother Morgan, prickt with proud disdaine,
Stird Porrex vp to put his brother downe;
The eldest brother did vntimely dy;
And brother vnto Cador Cornish king,
Whose brother Oswin, daunted with like dread,
Their brother to reproch and shamefull flight:
Where the third brother him did sore assay,
It was that Ollyphant, the brother deare
Whom when on ground his brother next beheld,
Of th'euill plight, in which her dearest brother
First to her brother, whom she loued deare,
Hate was the elder, Loue the younger brother;
The whilest their eldest brother was away,
Cupid their eldest brother; he enioyes
Then did my younger brother Amidas
And to my brother did ellope streight way:
My brother here declared hath to you:
After whose death, his brother seeing mee
Where brothers death to wreak Sansioy
That brothers hand shall dearely well requight
Of brothers prayse, to you eke longs his loue.
Vpon his brothers shield, which hong thereby:
For Aruirage his brothers place supplide,
Now haue three Moones with borrow'd brothers light,
Her natiue flesh, and staine her brothers bowre,
As in reuersion of his brothers right;
And throwne it vp vnto my brothers share:
Your brothers land the which the sea hath layd
Your brothers threasure, which from him is strayd,
Her brothers bones she scattered all about;
At length it brought them to a hollow caue,
The which at last out of the wood them brought.
Now when that ydle dreame was to him brought,
Who soone him brought into a secret part,
Had spent his lampe, and brought forth dawning light,
The Dwarfe him brought his steed: so both away do fly.
That many erra[n]t knights hath brought to wretchednesse.
Then brought she me into this desert waste,
Then beautie brought t'vnworthy wretchednesse
Yet wished tydings none of him vnto her brought.
Vnto this house he brought, and did bestow
And now he to her brought part of his stolen things.
That hath thee hither brought to taste mine yre?
So goodly brought them to the lowest staire
Entrapped slew, and brought to shamefull graue.
Can neuer rest, vntill it forth haue brought
And to him brought the shield, the cause of enmitie.
Home is he brought, and laid in sumptuous bed:
And brought the heauie corse with easie pace
From surging gulf two monsters straight were brought,
Them brought to ï¿½sculape, that by his art
To ï¿½sculapius brought the wounded knight:
Brought forth this monstrous masse of earthly slime,
Him to his castle brought with hastie forse,
But when he dyde, the Faerie Queene it brought
And said; faire Sir, I hope good hap hath brought
That brought not backe the balefull body dead;
To see his loued Squire into such thraldome brought.
So brought vnto his Lord, as his deserued pray.
Vnto old Timon he me brought byliue,
Hath brought you hither into Faery land,
Me hither brought by wayes yet neuer found,
And brought vnto him swords, ropes, poison, fire,
What grace hath thee now hither brought this way?
And trew Repentance they to Vna brought:
By this Charissa, late in child-bed brought,
To her faire Vna brought this vnacquainted guest.
The faultie soules from thence brought to his heauenly bowre.
Thence she thee brought into this Faerie lond,
And brought thee vp in ploughmans state to byde,
Lucina came: a manchild forth I brought:
When with one sword seuen knights I brought to end,
What hard mishap him brought to such distresse,
She brought to mischiefe through occasion,
And with him brought Priene, rich arayd,
(Said Guyon,) let that message to thy Lord be brought.
Now brought to him a flaming fire brond,
By this time was the worthy Guyon brought
Her ferry brought, where him she byding fond,
Tho him she brought abord, and her swift bote
At last him to a litle dore he brought,
Thence forward he him led, and shortly brought
He brought him through a darksome narrow strait,
He brought him in. The rowme was large and wide,
Into the world to guide him backe, as he him brought.
So backe againe, him brought to liuing light.
Which to that shadie delue him brought at last,
Which he had brought for Braggadocchio vaine.
That seuen-fold shield, which he from Guyon brought
And brought them vp into her castle hall;
Then Iet or Marble far from Ireland brought;
Thence she them brought into a stately Hall,
Till by a conduit pipe it thence were brought:
Was close conuaid, and to the back-gate brought,
And soone into a goodly Parlour brought,
Vp to a stately Turret she them brought,
Thence brought th[m] to the second roome, whose wals
By sea to haue bene fro[m] the Celticke mayn-land brought.
They brought forth Giants and such dreadfull wights,
From whence he brought them to these saluage parts,
And shortly brought to ciuill gouernaunce,
And wholesome Statutes to her husband brought;
An army brought, and with him battell fought,
Who brought with him the holy grayle, (they say)
And Hengist eke soone brought to shamefull death.
So halfe vnwilling from their bookes them brought,
Vpon the parts, brought into their bondage:
And to him brought, fresh battell to renew:
And all his labour brought to happie end,
That had from hoggish forme him brought to naturall.
And brought to ground, that neuer wast before;
Eftsoones them brought vnto their Ladies sight,
Thence they were brought to that great Ladies vew,
Brought her into those parts, and what inquest
Thou haue it lastly brought vnto her Excellence.
Hath hither brought, for succour to appele;
Arose, she bad her charet to be brought,
For loe great grace or fortune thither brought
She found, and brought it to her patient deare
Thither they brought that wounded Squire, and layd
Me brought? ah farre be such reproch fro mee.
Where also many plaints to her were brought,
And shortly asked her, what cause her brought
She brought her to her ioyous Paradize,
Hither great Venus brought this infant faire,
She brought her forth into the worldes vew,
She askt, what deuill had her thither brought,
With silly Virgin by aduenture brought
Sith brought she was now to so hard constraint,
He brought to her in bands, as conquered
Till her he had attaind, and brought in place,
And many hath to foule confusion brought.
Ere they into the lightsome world were brought,
And meant vnto her prison to haue brought,
I with me brought, and did to her present:
Or brutishly brought vp, that neu'r did fashions see.
Might fairer be. And then she forth her brought
And brought through points of many perilous swords:
What hard misfortune brought me to the same;
Remouing her, into his charet brought,
Thither he brought the sory Florimell,
Another knight, whom tempest thither brought,
Brought vnto balefull ruine, was by name
Them go to rest. So all vnto their bowres were brought.
Brought thee from balefull house of Proserpine,
On mighty kings and kesars, into thraldome brought.
A perilous fight when he with force her brought
And eke the Ladie selfe he brought away,
Brought in that mask of loue which late was showen:
He seemed brought to bed in Paradise,
Are quite deuourd, and brought to nought by little bits?
That she might see her childre[n]s thrids forth brought,
So Florimell with Ate forth was brought,
Whereof when newes to Triamond was brought,
And brought with her fro[m] thence that goodly belt away.
Then first Cambello brought vnto their view
By view of all the fairest to him brought,
Which being brought, about her middle small
But brought forth speeches myld, when she would haue missayd.
Ye gentle Knights, whom fortune here hath brought,
That at the length vnto a bay he brought her,
Since I was brought into this dolefull den;
But ah vnhappy houre me thither brought:
Me hether brought with him, as swift as wind,
Thence she them brought toward the place, where late
Them thether brought, and how their harmes befell.
Ne woman yet so faire, but he her brought
Him wretched thrall vnto his dongeon brought,
Then was I taken and before her brought:
Should wilfully be into thraldome brought,
But haue perforce him hether brought away.
Thence forth were brought to him aboue a score
And being brought in daunger, to relent too late.
Through which, when Paris brought his famous prise
And with him brought a present ioyfully
Whereof conceiuing, she in time forth brought
But to his bed was brought, and layd aboue,
And thence Apollo King of Leaches brought.
To wend with her. So thence him farre she brought
Is with the tide vnto an other brought:
And by him brought againe to Faerie land;
So backe he brought Sir Marinell againe;
Then forth he brought his snowy Florimele,
Yet in this coffer, which she with her brought,
Did aske, what cause brought that man to decay,
So brought vnto his Lord, where he did sit,
Me iustly terme, that to this shame am brought,
So being clad, she brought him from the field,
In womans bondage, Talus to her brought;
Brought in vntimely houre, ere it was sought.
Then Britomart vnto a bowre was brought;
And many brought to shame by treason treacherous.
Thence forth vnto the Idoll they her brought,
Into her pregnant bosome, forth she brought
She for a present to their Goddesse brought.
Whereof when newes to Radigund was brought,
Thenceforth she streight into a bowre him brought,
Which brought that Damzell, as his purchast pray;
Commaunded straight his armour to be brought,
He vp did take, and with him brought away,
That brought her backe. And comming present there,
And brought the pillage home, whence none could get it out.
Eftsoones brought forth the villaine, as they ment,
So he it brought with him vnto the knights,
Those two strange knights were to her presence brought;
Then was there brought, as prisoner to the barre,
Was brought to her sad doome, as here was to be seene.
Against her brought, to banish all remorse,
And reasons brought, that no man could refute;
He brought forth that old hag of hellish hew,
The cursed Ate, brought her face to face,
Then brought he forth, with griesly grim aspect,
Then brought he forth Sedition, breeding stryfe
Then brought he forth Incontinence of lyfe,
Which brought that land to his subiection,
But he had brought it now in seruile bond,
Whereof when newes was to that Tyrant brought,
Then in he brought her, and her shewed there
Surprized was, and to Grantorto brought,
She forth was brought in sorrowfull dismay,
Vnhappy Squire, what hard mishap thee brought
Brought aunswere backe, that ere he tasted bread,
Now brought to this? By this now may ye learne,
Whom on his backe he bore, till he him brought
With bleeding wounds, brought home vpon a Beare
With thinking to what case her name should now be brought.
Vnto his bowre was brought, and there vndrest,
Now brought her selfe, and blam'd her noble blood:
To leaue, till to her fathers house he had her brought.
Which answer when the groome returning, brought
That in another Canto shall to end be brought.
A certaine herbe from thence vnto him brought,
Thether he brought these vnacquainted guests;
That when that infant vnto him she brought,
To guide mens labours, brought them also ease,
If yet he were aliue, or to destruction brought.
Thence he him brought away, and vp conuayd
The damzell was attacht, and shortly brought
Ere she againe to Calepine was brought;
Were brought by errour, or by wreckfull wynde.
If such a beast they saw, which he had thether brought.
And taking vp brought home, and noursed well
What time the golden apple was vnto him brought.
And oft, when Coridon vnto her brought
